intro: Ptelea obcordata, commonly known as the western poison-ivy or western poisonwood, is a deciduous shrub native to the western United States. It belongs to the Anacardiaceae family, which includes other toxic plants like poison ivy and mango. The plant has compound leaves with three to five leaflets, and its small, yellowish-green flowers are followed by red, fleshy berries. Ptelea obcordata is known for its toxic sap, which can cause skin irritation in humans. It thrives in moist, well-drained soils and is often found in woodlands and along stream banks.
